awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Novel microalgae for high yield hydrogen production
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the development of a microalgae-based commercial hydrogen production process that will surpass current or developing technologies. A technology for low-cost, high purity, renewable, scalable hydrogen production can facilitate greater domestic energy independence. Many industries, such as the petro-chemical, chemical, and electronics sectors, would benefit from low-cost industrial hydrogen. Transportation and electric power generation industries would benefit from increased fuel efficiency. Environmental benefits include replacement of fossil fuels, switching hydrogen production from natural gas to sunlight and water, substantial emissions reduction. and reduction of airborne pollutants generated by coal- and natural gas-powered power plants. The goal of this project is to advance the use of engineered algae, in combination with recent advances in bioprocessing and hardware engineering, to manufacture clean, renewable hydrogen.                                                     

The proposed project will develop microalgae strains that generate high hydrogen yields using a novel metabolic engineering strategy. Hydrogen production rates are challenging to improve due to complicated metabolic pathways and gene regulation guarding hydrogen production. The proposed project will create advanced algal strains combining increased hydrogen production rates with robust growth under the target process conditions. The objectives are: 1) engineer the chimeric genes to implement the metabolic engineering strategy, 2) validate the engineered genes in algae overexpressing a proprietary hydrogenase gene cHYD1, 3) determine effects of genotypes of parental strains on the chimeric genes, 4) combine the best selected genes in the developed parental genotypes and generate new production strains; and 5) demonstrate adequate H2 production rates in the production strains under controlled testing conditions. This project will produce the desired production strain with greatly increased hydrogen rates in the target commercial process environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this NSF-funded SBIR Phase II project, AlPower has successfully developed advanced, metabolically-engineered, production lines of algae for manufacturing green, fuel-cell ready hydrogen. Green algae are known to produce hydrogen using carbon dioxide, sunlight and water as the main inputs. Despite numerous attempts to increase hydrogen production in algae by using different stress conditions and genetically engineering algae to increase hydrogenase activity, hydrogen production rates have proven difficult to increase due to the complexity of the hydrogen metabolic pathways.

Critical milestones were achieved during Phase II leading to the development of elite production lines of algae for commercial production of hydrogen. AlPower invented an innovative metabolic engineering strategy for engineering elite algal lines which resulted in robust performance in the commercially relevant environment. AlPower identified several potent genes to improve hydrogen production rates through a proprietary gene discovery strategy. Novel proprietary genes were created and used to metabolically engineer algae. The top production line greatly increased hydrogen production, by >500% compared to the best wild-type strain.

The AlPower method for synthetic gene engineering improved gene stability and function. Careful investigation of algal strains also contributed to enhanced performance and increased stability of the production lines. Remarkably, AlPower consistently generated production lines in this study that stably retained the potent transgene combinations for nearly three months. These results greatly exceed the transgene stability obtained previously. In fact, the obtained transgene stability enables cost-effective commercial use of the top production line.

AlPower has successfully developed and demonstrated a production process at the pilot scale, paving the way for commercialization. Furthermore, AlPower achieved technical feasibility using our novel production lines outdoors with a cost-effective, inorganic medium.

The feasibility of establishing commercially viable hydrogen distribution networks through small- and medium-sized agri-plants was explored to reduce hydrogen transportation costs. AlPower considered co-production of a high-value product from algal biomass as a strategy to downsize agri-plants. We successfully determined conditions for extracting plant-based protein from our algal biomass and showed commercial feasibility of large-scale protein production. The amino acid content of the extracted protein exceeded by quality that of soybean protein and was comparable to beef. When combined with the increased value of algal biomass achieved using AlPower proprietary hydrogen production process, the development of a commercially viable hydrogen production/ algal biomass system is now greatly de-risked.

Once fully developed, this technology will greatly increase availability of green, fuel-cell-ready hydrogen and contribute to the growth of a commercial hydrogen economy.  Additionally, this innovative technology will play a critical role in carbon dioxide sequestration, replacing existing technologies that generate substantial carbon dioxide emissions and release methane.

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2024
Modified by: Svetlana Oard
